docs.snippet: If an interest in conservation has inspired you to cross caviar from wild Caspian Sea sturgeon off your holiday shopping list, you still have plenty of choices. Germany, France, Italy, Israel, Dubai and Uruguay are some of the places that have jumped...
docs.lead_paragraph: If an interest in conservation has inspired you to cross caviar from wild Caspian Sea sturgeon off your holiday shopping list, you still have plenty of choices. Germany, France, Italy, Israel, Dubai and Uruguay are some of the places that have jumped into the business of farming sturgeon for caviar. California was one of the earliest to develop a caviar industry and now, more than 15 years of experience have paid off with consistent quality from the two producers, Sterling and Tsar Nicoulai. They are likely to be the least expensive sources for good caviar this season. Both companies offer several grades from a type of sturgeon called transmontanus, or white sturgeon, from basic black to some with larger beads and paler hints of gold and gray, at higher prices. It all has to do with how the roe is sorted as it is harvested. Samples purchased from www.sterlingcaviar.com and www.tsarnicoulai.com, showed stylistic differences between the products; which to choose is a matter of taste.
docs.abstract: Food Stuff column; California producers Sterling and Tsar Nicoulai are offering several grades of caviar from farmed sturgeon this holiday season; photo (S)

headline.main: Fresh From the Farm, California Caviar
